questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with hearing issues. During the examination, the audiologist performs the Bing Test and Gelle’s Test to assess the type of hearing loss. What would be indicative of conductive hearing loss in the Bing and Gelle tests?

options.A: Bing: No change; Gelle: No change

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bing: No change; Gelle: No change Explanation: Both Bing and Gelle’s tests will show negative results in conductive hearing loss, indicating no change in hearing. Aspect Bing Test Gelle's Test Purpose Assess the effect of ear canal occlusion on bone conduction (BC) hearing. Evaluates the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on BC hearing. Procedure A tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the ear canal is alternately occluded and unoccluded. A tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the air pressure in the ear canal is increased using Siegel’s pneumatic speculum. Normal/SNHL Finding Sound appears louder when the ear canal is occluded. (Positive) Hearing decreases with increased air pressure (Positive) Conductive Loss Finding No change in sound loudness with ear canal occlusion. (Negative) No change in hearing with increased air pressure (Negative) Note: Gelle’s test was primarily used to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis (Gelle’s negative). Nowadays, tympanometry is the investigation of choice for diagnosing stapes fixation in otosclerosis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 26,27

questions.question: A 68-year-old retired librarian has experienced a gradual decline in hearing ability in her right ear. She attributes this issue to ageing and consults an audiologist. The test results show a hearing level of 67 dB in her right ear. What is the grade of her hearing loss?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Moderately severe Explanation: The given case is diagnosed with presbycusis which is an age related hearing loss and the grade of hearing loss is moderately severe as per WHO’s classification. WHO (1980) recommended the following classification on the basis of pure tone audiogram taking the average of the thresholds of hearing for frequencies of 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz with reference to ISO: R. 389-1970 (International Calibration of Audiometers). Grade Range Mild (Option A) 26-40 dB Moderate (Option B) 41-55 dB Moderately severe (Option C) 56-70 dB Severe (Option D) 71-91 dB Profound >91 dB Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 44.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female with a recent upper respiratory infection presented with ear pain, fullness, hearing difficulties, and dizziness, along with increased pressure during flights and bending over. Which of the following tests is most reliable in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tympanometry Explanation: The above scenario suggests eustachian tube obstruction and the most reliable test for eustachian tube dysfunction is tympanometry , also known as the inflation-deflation test. Tests for Eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction Tympanometry/Inflation-deflation test (Option B) Principle: When a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. Normal: The ability of the tube to equilibrate positive and negative pressures to the ambient pressure. Pneumatic otoscopy Normal tympanic membrane (tested by otoscope or Siegle’s speculum): Mobile, shiny, pearly grey, has a concave lateral surface (umbo) and a bright light cone in the anteroinferior quadrant. Nasopharyngoscopy A flexible nasopharyngoscope can examine the pharyngeal end of the eustachian tube. Eustachian tube catheterisation A bent Eustachian tube catheter is passed through the nose to the nasopharynx, where a Politzer's bag is connected to insufflate air. Entry of air into the middle ear is confirmed using an auscultation tube. Valsalva (Option A) Principle: Create positive pressure in the nasopharynx to allow air into the Eustachian tube. Pinching the nose and taking a deep breath with a closed mouth helps blow air into the ears, moving the tympanic membrane outward. Contraindication: Pharyngitis and sinusitis Politzer test (Option C) In children who can't perform the Valsalva test, the olive-shaped tip of a Politzer's bag is used; compressing the bag causes the tympanic membrane to bulge. Toynbee manoeuvre (Option D) Toynbee’s manoeuvre causes a negative pressure in the nasopharynx, causing inward retraction of the tympanic membrane. Frenzel manoeuvre Performed by divers to equalise middle ear pressure underwater. Sonotubometry Measures Eustachian tube opening by applying sound through a nasal probe and recording changes in the external auditory canal during swallowing. Eustachian tube ventilatory function (researchgate.net)" data-tags="" height="1846" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/E9C9cWQOYfV5mq5ScXkI1738824277.png" width="4167" />

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy is referred to the ENT clinic for difficulty hearing in noisy environments and discomfort from loud sounds, affecting his school performance. Which of the following indicates cochlear pathology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Presence of recruitment Explanation: The presence of recruitment, i.e., abnormal growth of loudness, indicates cochlear pathology. Recruitment Description Example Use The ear that fails to detect low-intensity sounds begins to perceive higher-intensity sounds at levels as loud as or louder than those heard by a normal ear. As a result, a sound that is tolerable in a normal ear may become uncomfortably loud in the recruiting ear. Cochlear lesions: Meniere’s disease Presbycusis Distinguish cochlear pathology from retrocochlear. Tests to differentiate between cochlear and retro cochlear pathology: Normal Cochlear pathology Retrocochlear pathology Speech discrimination score 90-100% Below 90% Very poor Recruitment (Option D) Absent Present Absent SISI score (Option C) 0-15% >70% 0-20% Threshold tone decay Test (Option B) 0-15 dB <25 dB >25 dB Stapedial reflex (Option A) Present Present Absent Stapedial reflex decay Normal Normal Abnormal BERA Normal interval between wave I and V Normal interval between wave I and V Wave V delayed or absent Rollover phenomenon Absent primarily but seen in old age Absent Present Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test Identifies recruitment in cases of unilateral hearing loss. It assesses the perceived loudness differences between ears A tone is alternately presented to the normal and affected ear, adjusting the intensity in the affected ear to match the normal ear’s loudness.

questions.question: A 4-month-old was brought to the audiology clinic by his parents due to decreased responsiveness to environmental sounds, such as his name and household noises. Audiology tests were recommended. Which statement about the test shown in the image is correct?

options.A: Emissions are generated by inner hair cells
options.B: Spontaneous emissions are present in all individuals
options.C: Evaluates hearing in those with cognitive impairments

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Evaluates hearing in those with cognitive impairments Explanation: The image depicts Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) , a test in which emissions are generated by outer hair cells and are used to evaluate hearing in individuals with cognitive impairments. OAEs are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal. (Option A) Pathway: The absence of OAE indicates damage in the outer hair cell (conditions like lesions of the cochlea, middle ear disorders, etc.). Types: Spontaneous OAEs involve emissions without any external stimulation

questions.question: An infant was brought in due to concerns from her parents about her poor response to loud sounds and reduced reaction to environmental noises compared to her peers. The BERA test shows issues with wave V within the first 10 milliseconds. What site of pathology might this indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lateral lemniscus Explanation: The wave V in BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) represents lateral lemniscus. BERA (brainstem-evoked response audiometry) also known as Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is a non-invasive technique to assess the auditory pathway from the cochlea through the 8th cranial nerve to the brain stem. Electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz. In a normal person, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 ms indicating respective

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true about Electrocochleography(ECochG)?

options.A: Measures the electrical potentials generated in the cochlea and 8th cranial nerve
options.B: A normal SP/AP ratio is greater than 0.3 or 30%
options.C: Can differentiate cochlear pathology from 8th nerve lesions
options.D: Investigation of choice for Meniere's disease

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A normal SP/AP ratio is greater than 0.3 or 30% Explanation: A normal SP/AP ratio is less than 0.3 or 30% . If the ratio is greater than 0.3 or 30%, it is suggestive of endolymphatic hydrops, which is a hallmark of Meniere's disease. Electrocochleography (ECochG): Measures the electrical potentials generated in the cochlea and auditory portion of the 8th cranial nerve in response to auditory stimuli (Option A) Recorded within the first 2-3 ms, capturing cochlear microphonics, summating potentials, and 8th nerve action potentials Typically recorded using a thin needle electrode passed through the tympanic membrane onto the promontory Clinical Applications: Assess hearing thresholds in young infants and children with an accuracy of 5-10 dB Differentiate cochlear from 8th nerve lesions (Option C) Cochlear pathologies affect the cochlear microphonics and summating potentials 8th nerve lesions affect the action potentials A normal SP/AP ratio is <0.3 or <30% It is the investigation of choice for diagnosing Meniere's disease (Option D) Practical Considerations: It can be performed under local anesthesia in adults. Requires sedation or general anaesthesia in children and anxious patients. Sedation does not interfere with the recorded potentials. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 31

questions.question: A 5-year-old child undergoes acoustic reflex testing during an evaluation for suspected hearing loss. The results indicate the absence of stapedial reflexes at elevated sound levels. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this finding?

options.A: Normal hearing with no middle ear pathology

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Conductive hearing loss Explanation: The absence of stapedial reflexes at elevated sound levels suggests possible conductive hearing loss, such as fluid in the middle ear or ossicular chain dysfunction. While severe sensorineural hearing loss can also result in absent reflexes, elevated thresholds typically point to conductive issues. Normal hearing would not show absent reflexes, and mild sensorineural hearing loss is less likely to affect the reflex at elevated levels. Stapedial Reflex (Acoustic Reflex): It is an involuntary contraction of the stapedius muscle in response to loud sounds. This reflex serves to protect the inner ear from potentially damaging high sound levels and aids in sound localisation. Mechanism: Muscles Involved: The reflex involves the contraction of the stapedius muscle, which is attached to the stapes bone in the middle ear. Auditory Pathway: Upon detecting a loud sound, the auditory nerve sends signals to the brainstem, specifically to the cochlear nucleus and superior olivary complex. Reflex Arc: These signals then travel via the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), resulting in the contraction of the stapedius muscle. This contraction reduces the movement of the stapes, thereby limiting sound transmission to the inner ear. Clinical Significance: Testing: Acoustic reflex testing is performed using an impedance audiometer to assess the presence and thresholds of the reflex in response to sound stimuli. Interpretation of Results: Normal Reflex: Indicates intact middle ear function and hearing thresholds within normal limits. Absence of Reflex : Suggests conductive hearing loss (e.g., due to fluid or ossicular chain dysfunction) or severe sensorineural hearing loss. Elevated Thresholds: May indicate hearing loss while still showing reflexes at higher sound levels. Typical Findings: Reflex thresholds are typically measured in decibels hearing level (dB HL), with normal reflexes present around 70-90 dB HL.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic otitis media presents with progressive hearing loss. Impedance audiometry is performed. Which of the following findings would be pointing towards an underlying middle ear pathology?

options.C: A decreased physical volume of the external auditory canal
options.D: The presence of a robust acoustic reflex at normal sound intensities

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Type B tympanogram Explanation: Type B tympanogram , characterised by a flat, dome-shaped curve with no compliance changes , indicates middle ear pathology such as fluid or a thick tympanic membrane and is significant in hearing loss Impedance audiometry: Impedance audiometry comprises of acoustic reflex and tympanometry. Tympanometry : Measures the compliance (stiffness) of the tympano-ossicular system by detecting the reflected sound energy. Can also test Eustachian tube function by pressure changes and swallowing. Different tympanogram types indicate middle ear pathologies: Tympanogram Type Characteristics Indication Type A Normal peak Normal middle ear function Type As Shallow peak Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis) Type Ad Deep peak Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane Type B Flat, no peak Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane Type C Peak at negative pressure Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure Acoustic Reflex (Stapedial Reflex): Measures the stapedial muscle contraction in response to loud sounds (70-100 dB above threshold). Useful for: Assessing hearing in infants and young children. Detecting malingering. Diagnosing cochlear and CN VIII pathologies. Assessing facial nerve function and brainstem lesions. A decreased physical volume of the external auditory canal (Option C) : Increased volume (>2.5 mL in adults) (not decreased) would be more indicative of tympanic membrane perforation or ventilation tube patency. The presence of a robust acoustic reflex at normal sound intensities (Option D ) indicates a cochlear, rather than middle ear pathology for the hearing loss.

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman presents with progressive left ear hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve, more pronounced at 2000 Hz. Which of the following best describes this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Carhart's notch Explanation: The description of a dip in the bone conduction curve, more pronounced at 2000 Hz, is characteristic of the Carhart's notch seen in otosclerosis . This is due to the fixation of the stapes bone, which impairs sound transmission through the middle ear. Feature Otosclerosis Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) Air Conduction Loss, more pronounced at lower frequencies - Bone Conduction and Characteristic pattern Normal, may show "Carhart's notch" at 2000 Hz (5-15 dB loss) Typical notch at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction (Boiler's notch) (Option B) Hearing Loss Mixed Sensorineural Age-related hearing loss (Option C): Age-related hearing loss typically shows a gradual, symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, without the characteristic notched pattern. Meniere's disease (Option D)

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Conductive Hearing Loss Explanation: Given that the audiometric findings show a significant A-B gap with normal BC thresholds and poorer AC thresholds, the most likely diagnosis is Conductive Hearing Loss. This indicates an issue with the outer or middle ear, preventing effective transmission of sound to the inner ear. Pure Tone Audiometry: AC & BC are tested with the help of pure tones produced by Audiometer Charted in a graph called Audiogram It is a subjective test that relies on patient feedback to determine hearing thresholds across various frequencies. AC vs. BC (A-B Gap): Indicates the degree of conductive deafness. Aspect Air Conduction (AC) Bone Conduction (BC) Frequency Range 125 - 8000 Hz 250 - 4000 Hz Indicates Overall hearing sensitivity Cochlear function Normal Ear Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies) No significant A-B gap Conductive Hearing Loss AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal. BC Thresholds: Within normal limits. A-B Gap (>20db): Significant Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) (Option B) AC Thresholds: Elevated BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC. A-B Gap: Minimal or absent Presbycusis (Option C) AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies. BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies. A-B Gap: Minimal Downsloping Meniere’s Disease (Option D) Upsloping A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient is being evaluated for hearing loss using various tuning fork tests. What are the expected findings for a patient with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)?

options.A: Rinne: Positive; Weber: Affected ear; Bing: louder
options.B: Rinne: Positive ; Weber: Better ear ; Schwabach: Shorter
options.C: Rinne: Negative; Schwabach: Longer; Gelle’s: No change.
options.D: ABC: Same; Weber: Unaffected ear; Bing: No change with occlusion.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rinne: Positive; Weber: Better ear; Schwabach: Shorter Explanation: In a Patient with Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL), the expected findings from tuning fork tests are as follows: The Rinne test will be positive, indicating AC>BC. The Weber test will lateralise to the better ear, reflecting the diminished hearing in the affected ear. The Schwabach test will show a shorter duration of hearing compared to the examiner, indicating SNHL. Tuning fork test findings: Test Conductive Hearing Loss Sensorineural Hearing Loss Rinne Test BC > AC (negative) AC > BC (positive) Weber Test Lateralises to the affected ear Lateralises to the unaffected ear ABC Test Same duration as the examiner Shorter duration than the examiner Schwabach Test Longer duration than the examiner Shorter duration than the examiner Bing Test No change with occlusion (negative) Louder with occlusion (positive) Gelle’s Test No change with pressure (negative) Decreased hearing with increased pressure (positive) Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 26,27

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct sequence of structures involved in the transmission of sound from the external environment? → Tympanic membrane → Ossicles → Basilar membrane → Organ of Corti → Auditory nerve → Pinna → Ossicles → Cochlea → Auditory nerve → Organ of Corti → Pinna → Tympanic membrane → Organ of Corti → Cochlea → Basilar membrane → Cochlea → Ossicles → Tympanic membrane → Auditory nerve → Basilar membrane
questions.explanation: → Tympanic membrane → Ossicles → Basilar membrane → Organ of Corti → Auditory nerve Correct Answer: A) Pinna → Tympanic membrane → Ossicles → Basilar membrane → Organ of Corti → Auditory nerve Explanation: Sound transmission starts at the pinna , which collects sound waves and directs them to the tympanic membrane. Vibrations pass through the ossicles to the cochlea , where the basilar membrane and Organ of Corti convert mechanical energy into electrical impulses, transmitted to the brain via the auditory nerve. Sound Transmission Pathway: Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 17,18.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) undergoes hearing tests. The examiner performs the Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test and the Schwabach Test. What are the expected findings of the duration of both tests?

options.D: ABC - Shorter, Schwabach - Same as Examiner

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Both are Shorter Explanation: In SNHL, both tests reveal shorter hearing durations for the patient compared to the examiner. Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test: Purpose: To assess cochlear function by comparing the patient’s bone conduction (BC) hearing to that of a person with normal hearing. (Examiner is assumed to have Normal hearing) Procedure: The tuning fork is placed on the mastoid bone of both the patient and an examiner with normal hearing. Both the patient’s and examiner’s External auditory meatus are occluded (e.g., by pressing the tragus) to prevent ambient noise interference. Expected Findings: Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL): In SNHL, the patient’s cochlea is impaired, so they hear the bone conduction tuning fork for a shorter time. Conductive Hearing Loss: Both the patient and the examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration. Schwabach Test: Purpose: To compare the duration of bone conduction hearing between the patient and an examiner with normal hearing but without occluding the ear canals. Expected Findings: Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL): The duration of hearing the tuning fork is shorter for the patient compared to the examiner. Conductive Hearing Loss: The patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg - 26

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient presents with hearing loss. On examination, the Weber test indicates that the vibrations are lateralised to the left ear. Given the Weber test findings, which of the following conditions could explain these findings?

options.A: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
options.B: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
options.C: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
options.D: Normal hearing in the left ear

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Conductive hearing loss in the left ear Explanation: In this scenario, vibrations are lateralised to the left ear, which generally suggests that there is conductive hearing loss in the left ear. The sound is lateralised to the ear with conductive hearing loss due to the enhanced perception of bone-conducted sound in that ear . Weber test: Procedure: Strike a 512 Hz tuning fork (preferred) to make it vibrate. Place the vibrating fork on the centre of the patient’s forehead/vertex of the skull. Ask the patient to identify in which ear the sound is perceived as louder. Normal Finding: The sound is heard equally in both ears. Interpretation: Type of Hearing Loss Result Reason Conductive Hearing Loss (CHL) Sound lateralises to the affected ear In CHL, sound conducted through bone is perceived louder in the ear with impaired air conduction due to decreased ambient noise. Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) Sound lateralises to the unaffected (better) ear In SNHL, the sound is perceived to be louder in the ear with better cochlear function, as the affected ear struggles with both air-conducted and bone-conducted sounds. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg - 26

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulties. During the Rinne test, bone conduction (BC) is significantly better than air conduction (AC) in the right ear. The Weber test shows lateralisation to the right ear. What is the most likely cause of these findings?

options.A: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
options.B: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
options.C: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
options.D: Mixed hearing loss in the right ear

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Conductive hearing loss in the right ear Explanation: Given that the Rinne test shows BC > AC in the right ear and the Weber test shows lateralisation to the right ear, these findings are consistent with conductive hearing loss in the right ear. 1. Air Conduction (AC): Pathway: Air → Outer Ear → Ear Canal → Eardrum → Ossicles → Inner Ear In a healthy ear, AC is typically better than BC 2. Bone Conduction (BC): Bone conduction bypasses the outer and middle ear and directly stimulates the inner ear (cochlea) through vibrations applied to the skull. Pathway: Vibration → Skull Bones → Inner Ear (Cochlea) It helps to identify if there is a problem with the inner ear or the auditory nerve. Test Conductive Loss Sensorineural Loss Normal Hearing How to Perform Rinne Negative (BC > AC) Positive (AC > BC) Positive (AC > BC) Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone (BC). When sound is no longer heard, move it near the ear canal (AC). Weber Lateralises to worse ear Lateralises to better ear Heard equally Place the vibrating tuning fork on the midline of the forehead or the top of the head. Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Hears as long as the examiner Hears for a shorter duration Hears as long as the examiner Both the patient's and examiner’s ear canals are occluded. Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone. Schwabach Lengthened Reduced Normal Place the vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone. Compare the duration the patient hears the sound with the examiner’s hearing duration. False Negative Rinne Test: Seen in severe unilateral sensorineural (SN) hearing loss. Patient Response : Patient cannot perceive sound from the tuning fork via air conduction (AC). Responds to bone conduction (BC) testing, but this response is from the opposite ear due to transcranial sound transmission. Correct Diagnosis : Use masking of the nontest ear with Barany’s noise box during BC testing. Additional Testing: Weber Test: Lateralizes to the better hearing ear. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 26

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman with suspected conductive hearing loss undergoes a Rinne test using different tuning forks. The test reveals a better perception of sound through bone conduction compared to air conduction. Which tuning fork frequency is most likely used in this test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 512 Hz Explanation: The 512 Hz tuning fork is the standard choice for the Rinne test, Weber test and Absolute Bone Conduction test. It strikes a balance between not being too low (which would produce a strong vibration) and not being too high (which would fade quickly). This frequency provides a clear and sustained tone that allows for a reliable comparison of air conduction and bone conduction. Air-Bone Gap: Tuning Fork Test Result Predicted Air-Bone Gap (dB) Rinne test equal/negative for 256 Hz, positive for 512 Hz 20-30 dB Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz, positive for 1024 Hz 30-45 dB Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz 45-60 dB 256 Hz (Option A) produces a deeper tone with more prominent vibrations. While they can be used for tuning fork tests, they are not ideal for differentiating between air conduction and bone conduction because their primary function is to produce a strong vibratory sensation. 1024 Hz (Option C) produces a higher-pitched sound that tends to fade quickly. The rapid decay of the sound makes it less effective for the Rinne test, as it doesn’t allow for a prolonged comparison of air and bone conduction. 2048 Hz (Option D) is even higher and has an even shorter duration of sound. They are often used for more specific hearing assessments or research purposes rather than routine clinical tests like the Rinne test. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 26 Tuning Fork Frequency

questions.question: The image given below of the auditory pathway, depicts auditory signals travelling from the cochlea to the primary auditory cortex and passes through the following structures in sequences A, B, C, and D. Which sequence correctly identifies the order of these structures? Nucleus Complex Complex Colliculus

options.A: A - Cochlear Nucleus; B - Superior Olivary Complex; C - Inferior Colliculus; D - Medial Geniculate
options.B: A - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; B - Cochlear Nucleus; C - Inferior Colliculus; D - Superior Olivary
options.C: A - Inferior Colliculus; B - Cochlear Nucleus; C - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; D - Superior Olivary
options.D: A - Superior Olivary Complex; B - Medial Geniculate Nucleus; C - Cochlear Nucleus; D - Inferior

questions.explanation: - Medial Geniculate Nucleus

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with difficulty localising sounds and a reduced ability to discern speech in noisy environments. He reports no significant hearing loss. Imaging studies reveal normal cochlear and auditory nerve structures, but a lesion is detected in the brainstem. Which structure in the auditory pathway is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Superior olivary complex Explanation: The patient's symptoms, including difficulty localising sounds and trouble discerning speech in noisy environments, suggest that the lesion is in the superior olivary complex. The superior olivary complex (located in the pons) is responsible for sound localisation . It also involves processing complex auditory environments, such as distinguishing speech in noisy settings. Auditory pathway: Cochlea Cochlear Nerve Cochlear Nucleus (in the brainstem) Superior Olivary Complex Lateral Lemniscus Inferior Colliculus (in the midbrain) Medial Geniculate Nucleus (in the thalamus) Primary Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals are sent to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (Heschl’s gyrus) , where sound perception, including the identification of pitch, rhythm and speech occurs. Inferior colliculus (Option A) plays a key role in integrating auditory input and reflexive responses to sound. While it contributes to sound processing, its primary role is in coordinating reflexive responses to auditory stimuli and auditory attention. Cochlear nuclei (Option B) are the first point of synapse for auditory nerve fibres from the cochlea. They process basic aspects of sound before sending information to higher centres like the superior olivary complex. Medial geniculate body (Option D) is a relay station that passes auditory information from the brainstem (inferior colliculus) to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe. It helps in the conscious perception of sound, processing aspects like intensity and pitch.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of the phase difference between the oval and round windows in sound transmission?

options.A: It amplifies sound waves by 10 dB
options.B: It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement
options.C: It ensures simultaneous vibration of the oval and round windows
options.D: It decreases sound transmission efficiency, reducing hearing sensitivity by 4 dB

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement the round window is crucial in preventing the cancellation of sound waves. The oval window receives compression waves, while the round window experiences the rarefaction phase, allowing proper movement of the perilymph in the cochlea. Without this phase difference, sound waves reaching the two windows at the same time would cancel each other out, leading to no movement of the perilymph and ineffective sound transmission. It amplifies sound waves by 10 dB (Option A): The phase difference between the oval and round windows contributes to sound transmission but does not amplify sound by 10 dB. The actual contribution of the phase difference to hearing sensitivity is about 4 dB, not 10 dB . It ensures simultaneous vibration of the oval and round windows (Option C) : The oval and round windows do not vibrate simultaneously. In fact, their non-simultaneous movement is what prevents the cancellation of sound waves and ensures proper movement of the perilymph. It decreases sound transmission efficiency, reducing hearing sensitivity by 4 dB (Option D): The phase difference between the oval and round windows actually enhances sound transmission efficiency and contributes to increasing hearing sensitivity by about 4 dB , not decreasing it. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 18.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in his right ear. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, and an MRI shows no abnormalities in the cochlear nerve. A defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals is suspected. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Organ of Corti Explanation: The patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss, typically caused by damage to the inner ear or the neural pathways responsible for hearing. Given the defect in converting mechanical sound vibrations into electrical signals, the likely issue lies in the Organ of Corti, where the hair cells transduce sound vibrations into electrical impulses. The Organ of Corti , located on the basilar membrane inside the cochlea, contains the hair cells responsible for the hearing transduction mechanism . When sound waves are transmitted through the ear and reach the inner ear, they cause vibrations of the basilar membrane , which bend stereocilia on the hair cells. Inner hair cells are arranged in a single row, while outer hair cells form three to four rows. Inner hair cells transmit auditory stimuli to the brain, while outer hair cells modulate inner hair cell function to enhance sound sensitivity and clarity. This bending opens ion channels, generating electrical impulses. These impulses are sent through the auditory nerve to the brain, where they are interpreted as sound. Oval window (Option A) is a membrane-covered opening between the middle and inner ear. It plays a role in the mechanical conduction of sound by transmitting vibrations from the stapes to the fluid in the cochlea but is in converting those vibrations into electrical signals. Tympanic membrane (Option C) vibrates in response to sound and transmits from the external ear to the ossicles of the middle ear. Damage leads to conductive hearing loss but doesn't affect sound transduction. Stapes footplate (Option D): This structure amplifies sound waves but involves the conductive hearing process, not sensorineural conversion.

questions.question: What is the total amplification of sound in the auditory system due to impedance matching, considering both the lever action of the ossicles and the area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window?

options.A: 1.3 times from lever action × 17 times from area ratio = 22.1 times
options.B: 1.3 times from lever action × 20 times from area ratio = 26 times
options.C: 1.5 times from lever action × 22 times from area ratio = 33 times
options.D: 1.3 times from lever action × 14 times from area ratio = 18.2 times

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1.3 times from lever action × 14 times from area ratio = 18.2 times Explanation: The total amplification achieved by impedance matching in the auditory system results from the combined effects of two mechanisms: Area and Lever Ratios in the Middle Ear: Parameter Value Effective vibratory area of TM 45 mm² Footplate area 3.2 mm² Areal ratio 14:1 Lever ratio (ossicles) 1.3:1 Total transformer ratio 18.2:1 (approximately 18:1) Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 18.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is most important in the impedance-matching mechanism of the auditory system, facilitating the transfer of sound from the air-filled middle ear to the fluid-filled cochlea?

options.A: Acoustic Reflex of the Middle Ear Muscles
options.B: Area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window
options.C: Lever action of the malleus and stapes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Area ratio between the tympanic membrane and the oval window Explanation: The impedance-matching mechanism ensures efficient sound transmission from the air-filled middle ear to the fluid-filled cochlea. The tympanic membrane has a much larger surface area than the stapes footplate at the oval window. This area ratio, approximately 14:1, amplifies the sound pressure by concentrating the vibrations from a large surface (tympanic membrane) to a smaller one (oval window). This is the most significant contributor to impedance matching. The middle ear serves as an impedance-matching transformer, increasing the pressure of sound waves to overcome this mismatch. There are three key mechanisms involved in this process: Mechanism Description Function Lever Action of the Ossicles (Option C ruled out) The malleus has a longer handle compared to the incus , forming a lever system. Amplifies vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the stapes footplate by a factor of 1.3. Hydraulic Action of the Tympanic Membrane The tympanic membrane is larger than the stapes footplate, with an area ratio of about 21:1, reduced to 14:1 due to functional area. Concentrates force at the smaller stapes footplate, significantly increasing sound pressure. Curved Membrane Effect The tympanic membrane is slightly conical, causing greater vibrations at the periphery than at the centre. Increases the force applied to the ossicles, enhancing sound energy transmission. Acoustic Reflex of the Middle Ear Muscles (Option A) : Contraction of the stapedius and tensor tympani muscles in response to loud sounds reduces the amplitude of sound transmission but does not significantly contribute to impedance matching. Resonance of the basilar membrane (Option D) plays a role in frequency discrimination within the cochlea but is not part of the impedance-matching process in the middle ear. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 18.
